item.title: Things to consider before choosing a travel backpack
item.dc:creator: septychasanah
item.content:encoded:
Traveling with the right baggage is important. Because your baggage is where all your belonging are when you're traveling for long term. A bad decision in choosing a travel backpack may cost you a pain. There are many type of baggage available. From hard suitcase, soft suitcase,duffle bag, hiking backpack, add-on backpack with wheels or attachable daypack, and many more. Suitcase is perfect for cities travel with flat ground. But when it comes to hills and stairs, uneven ground and stony road, suitcase is not a good decision. Duffle bag only have one strap to put on the shoulders or 2 strap for hand carry. It is good for moving from one place to another but not for long walk because the weight is uneven. Hiking backpack is great, it is good for city travel or more of rural/nature area. However hiking backpack have a top loading and it's really is a pain when you need to access your backpack because all your staff are above each other and there is a case that you'll need to load and pack them back together just to take some stuff. Wheels backpack is also good. When you feel tired carrying your backpack, just pull the lever and you are good to go. But you'll need a good padded back when you choose this backpack, it is not comfortable to have a solid metal at your back. And most of wheels backpack have more weight to carry. So, choosing the right travel backpack is an important decision.  

Why carry on backpack?

With carry on backpack, you'll save more time checking your baggage. We have heard many stories about checking baggage from missing baggage, stolen items, damages, or the airline asking for extra money because your backpack is over the weight limit. According to the airline baggage restrictions, carry on baggage should have maximum56cm 45cm 25cm (22 inches 18 inches 10 inches). or maximum 46 liters. Do you think its too small? Especially because you will traveling for long term and you need a lot of stuff on the road. No, not exactly. There are many carry on backpack which offer spacious compartment. And honestly, do you really think you will need all that stuff? Many travelers who over packing during their first years ended up ditches most of their items and go lighter. There is no need to packed extra item which you'll never wear/use anyway. Carry on backpack maximum weight is 10 kg (varies between airlines, although some of them don't have weight restrictions). It will save your back and shoulders from pain then carrying around 55-75 liters backpack. Travel faster and lighter with only carry on backpack is the easiest and the best choice.  

Things to consider before choosing a travel backpack

I was basically spend many hours and days to finally choose the right fit. I read every review and watched many Youtube video to see learn each of them more closely. After so many win and errors in choosing travel backpack, I found the perfect basic requirement for carry on travel backpack. Here I put together basic requirement in choosing carry on travel backpack.

1. Comfortable

I will carrying around my backpack for at least 10-15 minutes or even longer so I will need a comfortable backpack. A backpack which is specially designed for woman is a good choice for me. Among other things are straps and padding.

2. Compartment and organized pocket

At least 2 compartment is essential. One main compartment for clothes and the other compartment for "most use" item. And also a padded laptop compartment to keep your laptop safe. And for small things like notepad, pen, boarding pass, phone, sunglasses etc we will need some extra pocket for easy access when we need them. Some backpack come with extra pockets in their main compartment.

3. Straps

You're going to need a comfortable padded straps if you need to walk for at least 15 minutes. Padded straps, shoulder's strap, chest strap and hip belt. Hip belt or even better padded hip belt help a lot if your backpack has it featured. Its essential for spreading the weight over your body. A hip belt can carry 80-90% of your packs weight, according to REI and Outdoor Gear Lab. Shoulder strap is also another must have requirement for a good backpack. That way your backpack will fit nicely and comfortable. It will help to avoid shoulder and back pain.

4. Waterproof

Rain, rain everywhere. A light rain or a quick run through the rain is okay. But not when it's a heavy rain, there is nothing much you can do to keep your backpack dry. Some of popular backpack use waterproof material likepack clothnylon or come with a rain cover attached.But if your backpack don't have a rain cover attached or if your backpack is waterproof but you want extra protection, you can buy a rain cover.

Check the price of rain cover in Amazon

5. Safety

Some backpack have anti theft feature like reliable material (hard to cut by a knives), hidden zipper, special zipper, straps, or zipper lock with pin. Choose the one that suit you and fit your budget. If your backpack doesn't have a zipper lock, and you consider to have one for your precious backpack, get a TSA approved zipper lock. Most of them came with pin combination.

Check the price of zipper lock in Amazon

I will also add a backpack protector for whenever I stay in a hostel, taking a bus, train. Pacsafe have this beautiful backpack protector to keep your backpack from getting stolen. Just lock your backpack in the unmovable chair or bed to keep them safe.

Check the price of pacsafe backpack protector in amazon

6.Warranty

Consider having a warranty for your backpack is a plus. Many backpack offer one year to 10 years of guarantee. Some of them even offer a lifetime guarantee like Osprey.Osprey willrepair any damage or defect for any reason free of charge. Whether it was purchased in 1974 or yesterday.   Ready to do your research for your best travel backpack? If you have any advise for choosing a travel backpack, please leave a comment to help others choose their best travel backpack.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: septychasanah
item.content:encoded:
Hi there! I'm Septy. Nerdy girl who love to spend a lot of time in front of laptop as much as in the beach. An adventurous girl who always love to see and try something new.Have been dreaming to see the beauty of the world and be part of it. Beside traveling around the globe, I am a Web/UI/UX Designer and Front End Developer. I love to make a beautiful design to help business owner grow their business. Welcome to my travel and digital nomad blog. Here I share with you my interesting stories about travel, digital nomad, travel tips, adventures and many more.  

Why Globe Roving?

Two years ago I realize that I could never settled. I keep moving from one city to another and I always want to move to another place. With my long time dream to visit England and my dislike of working at the office. I realize that I should travel. Beside my job that is easily done everywhere as long as I have internet connection and I dont have to stay in one place. I want to live everywhere I want. And also I have the opportunity to see the beauty of the world and discover many things that I never know before.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Hi there! I'm Septy. Nerdy girl who love to spend a lot of time in front of laptop as much as in the beach. An adventurous girl who always love to see and try something new.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: septychasanah
item.content:encoded:
Who We Are

The website is about travel and digital nomad. Its share interesting stories about travel, digital nomad, travel tips, adventures and many more. The one person behind this website is Septy Chasanah. Please read about page for more detail. The website address is:https://globeroving.com  

What Personal Data We Collect and Why We Collect It

By default WordPress does not collect any personal data about visitors, and only collects the data shown on the User Profile screen from registered users. Comments When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitors IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection. An anonymised string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment. Media If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website. Contact forms Akismetis enabled on the site, the contact form submission data IP address, user agent, name, email address, website, and message is submitted to theAkismetservice for the sole purpose of spam checking. The actual submission data is stored in the database of the site on which it was submitted and is emailed directly to the owner of the form (i.e. the site author who published the page on which the contact form resides). This email will include the submitters IP address, timestamp, name, email address, website, and message. The IP address and user agent originally submitted with the comment are synced, as well, as they are stored in post meta. Cookies This site uses cookies small text files that are placed on your machine to help the site provide a better user experience. In general, cookies are used to retain user preferences, store information for things like shopping baskets, and provide anonymised tracking data to third party applications like Google Analytics. As a rule, cookies will make your browsing experience better. However, you may prefer to disable cookies on this site and on others. The most effective way to do this is to disable cookies in your browser. If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year. Embedded content from other websites Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website. These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website. Analytics This feature sends page view events (and potentiallyvideo play events) over to Google Analytics for consumption.

Activity Log

To deliver this functionality and record activities around site management, the following information is captured: user email address, user role, user login, user display name, WordPress.com and local user IDs, the activity to be recorded, the WordPress.com-connected site ID of the site on which the activity takes place, the sites Jetpack version, and the timestamp of the activity. Some activities may also include the actors IP address (login attempts, for example) and user agent. Login attempts/actions, post and page update and publish actions, comment/pingback submission and management actions, plugin and theme management actions, widget updates, user management actions, and the modification of other various site settings and options. Retention duration of activity data depends on the sites plan and activity type.

Ads

Third party vendors, including Google, use cookies to serve ads based on a users prior visits to the website. Googles use of the DoubleClick cookie enables it and its partners to serve ads to your users based on their visit to your sites and/or other sites on the internet. Users may opt out of the use of the DoubleClick cookie for interest-based advertising by visiting Ad Settings.

Sharing

When sharing content via email, the following information is used: sharing partys name and email address (if the user is logged in, this information will be pulled directly from their account), IP address (for spam checking), user agent (for spam checking), and email body/content. This content will be sent toAkismetso that a spam check can be performed. Newsletter Newsletter plugin stores subscribers data in the blog database and does not transfer any data any services or website. We store many information about the subscribers: from theemail addresstonameandsurnameandIPs.  

How Long We Retain Your Data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognise and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue. For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information. What Rights You Have Over Your Data If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes. Where We Send Your Data Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.   Last update on October 27, 2018

Who we are

In this section, you should note your site URL, as well as the name of the company, organisation, or individual behind it, and some accurate contact information.

The amount of information you may be required to show will vary depending on your local or national business regulations. You may, for example, be required to display a physical address, a registered address, or your company registration number.

Suggested text: Our website address is: https://globeroving.com.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

In this section you should note what personal data you collect from users and site visitors. This may include personal data, such as name, email address, personal account preferences; transactional data, such as purchase information; and technical data, such as information about cookies.

You should also note any collection and retention of sensitive personal data, such as data concerning health.

In addition to listing what personal data you collect, you need to note why you collect it. These explanations must note either the legal basis for your data collection and retention or the active consent the user has given.

Personal data is not just created by a user’s interactions with your site. Personal data is also generated from technical processes such as contact forms, comments, cookies, analytics, and third-party embeds.

By default WordPress does not collect any personal data about visitors, and only collects the data shown on the User Profile screen from registered users. However some of your plugins may collect personal data. You should add the relevant information below.

Comments

In this subsection you should note what information is captured through comments. We have noted the data which WordPress collects by default.

The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

In this subsection you should note what information may be disclosed by users who can upload media files. All uploaded files are usually publicly accessible.

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

By default, WordPress does not include a contact form. If you use a contact form plugin, use this subsection to note what personal data is captured when someone submits a contact form, and how long you keep it. For example, you may note that you keep contact form submissions for a certain period for customer service purposes, but you do not use the information submitted through them for marketing purposes.

Cookies

In this subsection you should list the cookies your web site uses, including those set by your plugins, social media, and analytics. We have provided the cookies which WordPress installs by default.

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you have an account and you log in to this site, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

In this subsection you should note what analytics package you use, how users can opt out of analytics tracking, and a link to your analytics provider’s privacy policy, if any.

By default, WordPress does not collect any analytics data. However, many web hosting accounts collect some anonymous analytics data. You may also have installed a WordPress plugin that provides analytics services. In that case, add information from that plugin here.

Who we share your data with

In this section, you should name and list all third-party providers with whom you share site data, including partners, cloud-based services, payment processors, and third party service providers, and note what data you share with them and why. Link to their own privacy policies if possible.

By default WordPress does not share any personal data with anyone.

How long we retain your data

In this section you should explain how long you retain personal data collected or processed by the web site. While it is your responsibility to come up with the schedule of how long you keep each dataset for and why you keep it, that information does need to be listed here. For example, you may want to say that you keep contact form entries for six months, analytics records for a year, and customer purchase records for ten years.

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognise and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

In this section, you should explain what rights your users have over their data and how they can invoke those rights.

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

In this section, you should list all transfers of your site data outside the European Union and describe the means by which that data is safeguarded to European data protection standards. This could include your web hosting, cloud storage, or other third party services.

European data protection law requires data about European residents which is transferred outside the European Union to be safeguarded to the same standards as if the data was in Europe. So in addition to listing where data goes, you should describe how you ensure that these standards are met either by yourself or by your third-party providers, whether that is through an agreement such as Privacy Shield, model clauses in your contracts, or binding corporate rules.

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

In this section, you should provide a contact method for privacy-specific concerns. If you are required to have a Data Protection Officer, list their name and full contact details here as well.

Additional information

If you use your site for commercial purposes and you engage in more complex collection or processing of personal data, you should note the following information in your privacy policy in addition to the information we have already discussed.

How we protect your data

In this section you should explain what measures you have taken to protect your users’ data. This could include technical measures such as encryption; security measures such as two-factor authentication; and measures such as staff training in data protection. If you have carried out a Privacy Impact Assessment, you can mention it here too.

What data breach procedures we have in place

In this section, you should explain what procedures you have in place to deal with data breaches, either potential or real, such as internal reporting systems, contact mechanisms, or bug bounties.

What third parties we receive data from

If your website receives data about users from third parties, including advertisers, this information must be included in the section of your privacy policy dealing with third-party data.

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

If your web site provides a service which includes automated decision making - for example, allowing customers to apply for credit, or aggregating their data into an advertising profile - you must note that this is taking place, and include information about how that information is used, what decisions are made with that aggregated data, and what rights users have over decisions made without human intervention.

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

If you are a member of a regulated industry, or if you are subject to additional privacy laws, you may be required to disclose that information here.

item.title: Work With Me

item.content:encoded:
First thing first. While Im busy taking care of Globe Roving. Im basically a web - graphic - UI/UX designer and front end developer. I also work with wordpress. You can take a look at my portfolio here: http://senucha.com  

These are several services that I offer

 

Web Design

I have two web design service:
  • Mockup only
  • Mockup and html
I can help you design your website based on your need. My design are original and fully responsive to all devices. You can contact me directly here or work with me in upwork or fiverr (I have a very big discount if you hire me through fiverr although its only for mockup/prototype).
 

Graphic Design

Branding Identity, Flyer & Business card, Banner & Brochure, Social Media Cover & Vector Object.You can contact me directly here or work with me in upwork or fiverr(I have a very big discount if you hire me through fiverr)
 

Mobile App Design

If you building a mobile app and need some professional designer. I am that person. I also enlist my mobile app service in fiverr here. Or you can contact me directly here or work with me in upwork.
 

Wordpress

Wordpress design, theme customization, blog, website, you named it. Although Im not a developer which means I cant create a system inside wordpress. Feel free to contact me directly here or work with me in upwork or fiverr.

item.title: What I learned from my freelance fail
item.dc:creator: septychasanah
item.content:encoded:
I know that I don't want to spend the rest of my productive age to work in a cubicle. I know that one day I want to run my own business. I don't want to just work at the office and have the same regular day everyday, waiting for Friday to come at Monday, wishing to have a long weekend. And only able to take 12 days of holiday in a year. I've become comfortable and entered my comfort zone that I don't need to worry about how to get a money for tomorrow, because weather or not I had a job to do today at the office. I will still get paid at the end of the month. The possibility of me to grow inside the office is very unlikely. I keep getting the same job without any new challenges. It really hit me in my chess that I have to take an action and do it now. I have to get out there, somewhere. Take the risk, go to an adventure and create the memory. If its not now, when? I won't be this young next year.  

The journey start

The beginning of my freelance career start at 2015, while I still working at the office. It is not like what we imagine as "flexible working hours", "I don't need to commute", "I don't have a limitation of the job", "I don't need to deal with the office drama anymore", "I am the boss, I can take a holiday where ever I want". It really is a hard work. I'm dozing off after work and forgot to submit any proposal, too tired to finish a job and catch deadline because I only have few hours after dinner. Sometimes I sneak out at the office to work on my freelance job. So when I finally have enough saving and really tired of working at the office (no holiday for 2 years). I quit my job and decided to be a full time freelancer while learning of how to be an entrepreneur. By that means looking for clients on my own, marketing, networking, accounting, project management etc. It really need a courage and bravery to take the risk and give up everything. My freelance career is not a happy story, just like any other thousand freelancer out there. I have been in a few freelance website, here are the few of them

1. 99 Design

I joined a few contest, even got into final step but no win. The client keep asking for changes here and there and I had finally reached my patient and giving up. I let other contestant win because I cant deal with it any longer. It might be a wrong decision since I was giving up at the last stage. Although I didnt regret it. Ive spend so much time and effort in contest yet I still have to compete with other freelancer to win. Lucky if I win, I will get the price. Otherwise, all those time Ive spend is too precious to do unpaid work. Not going to come back.

2. Envato

Okay, envato is not a freelance site. But it is a marketplace where freelancer can sell their work online. It is the biggest marketplace at the moment. Although now envato have launch envato studio where people can hire freelancer. I was too confident by submitting a HTML template to themeforest on my first few months learning web design. And also submitted 2 logo template to graphic river, also as a newbie in graphic design. I know that it will be too easy to be rejected, and I was too soon to give up. However soon after that my HTML template landed me my second job and so I withdraw from envato. PS: Im not giving up yet, I will try again in the future.

3. Toptal

Being in toptal is like a dream come true because they only hire top 3% freelancer. Although that 3% freelancer is no longer valid since there are more freelancer in toptal. The screening process is very strict. There are five step of them. I had an interview and send portfolio sample but never goes to the next step. Once you failed you had to wait for a year to reapply, and it is not a guarantee that you will be accepted. Not going to come back.

4. Fiverr

I made 2 gig in fiverr to start. Everyone charging for $5. It is a disaster. You cant submit any proposal, there are hundreds of people offering the same service as you. And buyer request is so limited and not always what you're expected. So I just made my gig and let it there, until about a year later I got an email that I got an order. I made 3 sales with the same client. Today, I made 3 more new gigs and trying to be active as I can in hoping to get another order.

5. Upwork

Lucky me that I made an account in Upwork 2 years ago at 2016. There is no selection that time. During my attempt in having a job in Upwork I have sent hundreds of proposals, I spend all my connection in 2 week once. I got invited to some jobs, no message back. Having some interview and no hired. I left Upwork for a while and get back with surprise, they locked my profile private because I didnt earn any in a month. So they have put me into inactive mode where no one can invite me and my profile will no longer appear in search result. What? Seriously? Im having a hard time to come back and sending proposals, because people only able to view my profile if I submitted a proposal to them. Three months ago I finally able to make my profile back to public after some googling. You have to submit a request to put your profile back to public and have to do the exactly same procedure every time your profile went back to private. I still dont know the magic to conquer Upwork. I read some comment in Facebook group advising to just forget Upwork because you will not get a decent job from there.

6. Guru

I sign up to guru based on recommendation of my fellow freelancer I met online. We only able to submit 10 bids/proposals per month and I spend them all in just a week. I think guru is harder than upwork since I never got any message back and they have these rank of recommendation for all the bidders. But that rank doesnt guarantee you got the job, such a curious.  

What I learn from my freelance fail?

After all the upside down of being a freelancer, I learn my lesson. There is a time that I just want to give up. And go back to the office, have a normal boring day and never catch my dream. And then I remember what the alchemist said to the shepherd's boy in "The Alchemist" novel by Paulo Coelho.

"And, when you want something, all the universe conspires in helping you to achieve it."

Just don't give up on your dreams. What ever it takes, just give it a try. This is what I learned from my freelance fail.

1. Inconsistency and failed to organized

I don't have a schedule and structural management to keep me organized. I did not send proposal regularly. Yesterday I send 2 proposal, and then no proposal at all for the rest of the week. I don't have a goal on how much proposal I want to send per day. Which website I should visit today, and what kind of client I want to work for. I really need to planning out everything and keep everything in place. So I use freelance tool and time management to keep me organized. I made a to do list of what I want to do tomorrow and set a goal for every week.

2. I was a robot

I send proposal like a robot using proposal template. I don't really know how to write a good proposal and send the same proposal to every job. No wonder client didn't even look at my proposal, it's just another spammy proposal. I didn't take an effort to really understand the client and offer a solution to their problem. A client looking for a freelancer to help them solve their problem. And I wasn't talk to them like a human being. A good proposal don't need to be long and boring. Listing all your skills and even those skills that client did not need. They don't care how much your experience is, as long as you can give them the solution they need. So I take an extra time to understand what client's need and put together all the approach and solution to the client. Sometimes I take a time to make a sample design of what I offer. I didn't do that much. I will not do the job before the client hire me.

4. Let the stress of failure taking over me

My saving is running out and I still don't get any client. I start applying for regular job at the local agency but failed to turn up for the interview because I didn't want to go back to the office. I lower my rate as low as possible to get a client but honestly, I just make my self worthless by doing that. I'm no different with those freelancer who "do everything for $5". I also start applying to jobs that I don't like or that crappy job with very little money. The only motivation that I have is me. If I don't work hard, how will I survive? No one will give me money out of nowhere. The fear of failure overwhelmed me. Being born in 3rd world country makes us difficult to gain trust and decent jobs. Clients want to pay me just like everyone else who is born in 3rd world countries because the cost of living is low. Well, if you take a look at certain things, it is basically the same.  

Summary

Knowing how much I lost and sacrifice for my freelance career make me realize how much I dedicated my self into it. Sometimes we need to fail to pick up again our self and just do it again. Do it more, bigger and stronger.
I learned a lot from my failure, I took them as a lesson to do it better. I will just take one step forward and reach one more mile. Because one mile will lead to another. If you have encounter the same experience, please contribute your advice in the comment section for us to learn.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The beginning of my freelance career start at 2015, while I still working at the office. It really need a courage and bravery to take the risk and give up everything. My freelance career is not a happy story, just like any other thousand freelancer out there. I learned a lot from my freelance fail, I took them as a lesson to do it better.

item.title: The thought about dream and life
item.dc:creator: septychasanah
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes we sure and convince that our passion is one thing but later in life we do different thing. We see a very talented violist whos finally giving up on being a violist to become something else. She became the kingdom of her kingdom. For the last couple of months Ive been experiencing the same thing.
When I was a little girl I told everyone that I want to be a painter. But that dreams vanish when my sister said to me that I can paint as a profession. I can do it as a hobby and things I do while Im not working and have more stable job for living. Over the years I tried to paint. There is a time when I lost my passion to do so and I stop all over. I have never been serious in doing it, as so it sort of disappeared.
Then there is a time when I want to be pianist, never did it. I am a failed musician, I never learn piano because of my unfortunate life. Im dreaming that one day I will buy my own piano and find a personal teacher for myself. Not that I buried that dream too. I will still want to do it one day. But I never want it to be my profession. I do learn virtual piano and having a hard time to practicing my left hand. I know that I will need a real piano in order to balance both my hands.
I always believe that inside of me have to do with drawing and art my whole life. And so there is a time when I want to be an architect. I design some houses out of my imagination and attempted to pursue my career as an architect because I always drawn by the shape of building and their beauty. But I never done it too? Why? Because I live in different society that doesnt see art as a profession. Although as far as I knew, what I want to do for life is all connected t art. Because deep down in my heart I knew that I am an artist.
Maybe it was running in the family but none of them really want to execute it as a profession. But not me. And so I have the difficulty to reach my dreams. They see my other ability in education and the land of mathematics, they turn me to be a scholar and want me to end up just like them. To be one of them, a teacher. But I denied their expectations years ago and finally erase myself from my ability in math completely a few years ago.
So what do I do now, I find an alternative which will led me to more comfortable life that my predecessor. I choose the land of information technology. In there I pour everything my ability and my talent because the field is vast. I do architecture, I do drawing, and teaching. There is a time when I dont really know what I want to focus and ended up in my first job.
Spending a year and a half not knowing what is it really my position in the company until I left because I feel unhappy of doing something that I dont like. I throw everything and risk everything and start a new life. I dedicated my time and efforts to go back to drawing, in a different way, but still want to earn a living.
I remember someone saying that we have to love our job in order that we dont feel like working. A decision I made when I finally left my first job. Having a difficult times to considering to enroll a class in interior design for a year to get myself and piece of paper to start my new career and an interior designer or continuing my journey in IT but pour my passion in drawing. I did the latter, I spend months focusing myself learning web design and front end programming, attempted to start my entrepreneur wish and start looking for a new job. And so I dedicated myself in this field for almost four years. I became a professional and I want to be known.
Will this is become my forever profession I want to do for life? No, I dont think so. Almost a year ago I came home and helping my mom sorting off all my old books to sell them and only save books and documents that is important. While going through all that pile of books, essays, documents and everything. I found my old script about a play I wrote in high school. I read it and couldnt believe my younger me that I have a talent to be a writer and what I write was pretty good.
For all this time since my college years I keep telling myself and people around me that I cant write. While now I am stumble in a manuscript of my first ever portfolio to be a script writer. That manuscript is not the only one I wrote in my high school years. I wrote short stories and poems, even lyrics. Even my friend asking me for my stories, she want to read them.
During my college years and working at the office, my friends keep telling me that Im so lucky to be a person with a talent. They think they dont have any talent and dont know their purpose in life. That I have a passion to live for. Maybe I should be thankful for that. But I believe that when we focus on doing something and we really do it with our heart, something that we love, we will be good at that.
Will I turn myself to writing and once again change my career and direction? Or will I stay keep in close with drawing and continue to be a designer? I started to ask myself what my friends and other people asking about them self. What is the purpose of my life, Ive been thinking to do some spiritual journey to find that soul. To find my soul and my destiny. After all a life is a journey. To find our self. Because at this very moment I have the feeling that I will start a new journey that is completely different which will cost my whole career.
I found the feel to write again, and couple of years ago I met someone whos open my mind for me to discover myself. It changed me completely, that I need to do s spiritual journey to find my soul and discover my destiny. I will not planning to do a meditation alone a completely strange forest for a month or even spend years in a cave to find the cause of suffering and finally reach inner peace and feel enlighten. No, Im not going to do that.

item.title: October 2018 reading list: self development book
item.dc:creator: septychasanah
item.content:encoded:
I know its a middle of the month already. But I still want to read all this book. I've read some of them and want to re-read it again. Every month I will post my reading list as a journal and maybe you'll interested to read them. My October reading list is about self help/self development book, I still need those book to keep me motivated. So, here they are:

1. The Alchemist

By Paulo Coelho
I've read this book. And I want to re-read it again. It's about a young shepherd boy who had a dream that he will discover a treasure in the Egyptian pyramids. From there he met several people that will led him to his treasure in Egypt. This book teach us about the essential of listening to our heart, to discover our destiny and to read the omens along the way and to reach our dreams. Buy "The Alchemist" book in Amazon

2. The Power of Now: A Guide to Spiritual Enlightenment

ByEckhart Tolle
I've read this book as well. But honestly, I don't understand it. So I decided to re-read it again. It is about the essential of living in the "NOW", not in the past nor the future. To really be "in the now" and the powerful of "the now". It's more like a spiritual book to focus our conscious mind toliving in the present moment and avoiding thoughts of the past or future. Okay, I already said that before. The point is only the present moment is important. We don't exactly live in the now because we always thought about our past and future. That the thought about past and future is created by our mind, and also the illusion that our mind created will only bring us pain. Alright, that is hard to understand. At least for me. Buy "The Power of Now" book in Amazon

3.Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking

By Susan Cain
As an introvert, I have the difficulty to overcome my introvert.I only start reading this book. In this book, we will learn of how much we can do as an introvert and how to not undervalue our introvert. That it is fine to be introvert, we can also be successful just like any other people. Weather they are introvert or extrovert. There are also real stories of introvert people experiences.This bookhas the power to permanently change how people see introverts and, equally important, how wee see ourselves. Buy "Quiet" book in Amazon

4. Think and Grow Rich

By Napoleon Hill
I haven't read this book at all. According to Amazon, this book will teach you the secrets that could bring you a fortune. It will show you not only what to do but how to do it. Once you learn and apply the simple, basic techniques revealed here, you will have mastered the secret of true and lasting success. And according to Wikipedia, the book asserts that desire, faith, and persistence can propel one to great heights if one can suppress negative thoughts and focus on long-term goals. I'll add my review after I read this book. Buy "Think and Grow Rich" book in Amazon

5.The Power of Positive Thinking

By Norman Vincent Peale
I love the title. Being positive is always the best thing in life. In this book we will learn how to: expect the best and get it, believe in yourself and in everything you do, develop the power to reach your goals, break the worry habit and achieve a relaxed life, improve your personal and professional relationships, assume control over your circumstances and how to be kind to yourself.I'll add my review after I read this book. Buy "The Power of Positive Thinking" book in Amazon

6.Thinking, Fast and Slow

By Daniel Kahneman
According to this book summary, there are two system in our mind that drive the way we think. The first one is fast, intuitive and emotional. And the second isslower, more deliberative, and more logical.It offers practical and enlightening insights into how choices are made in both our business and our personal lives and how we can use different techniques to guard against the mental glitches that often get us into trouble. This book will transform the way we think about thinking.I'll add my review after I read this book. Buy "Think and Grow Rich" book in Amazon   Do you have any self hep/self development book recommendation? I would be happily take a look at them. Please share your review in the comment section bellow.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: My October reading list is about self help/self development book, I still need those book to keep me motivated. So, here they are:

item.title: Globe Roving "Want more clients and customers?"
item.content:encoded:
From: angelina subbs Subject: Want more clients and customers?
Message Body: Hi
We did check your website and it is not on the first page of Google.
We are hereby offering our services to get you on the first page of Google so you can get more inquiries, leads, and sales from your website.
Please email us back for the full proposal.
Best Regards
angelina
-- This e-mail was sent from a contact form on Globe Roving (https://globeroving.com)

item.title: Globe Roving "We offer you the opportunity to advertise your products and services."
item.content:encoded:
From: DonaldRiz Subject: We offer you the opportunity to advertise your products and services.
Message Body: We offer you the opportunity to advertise your products and services. Hello! That is a good offer for you. I can help you with sending your commercial offers or messages through feedback forms. The advantage of this method is that the messages sent through the feedback forms are included in the white list. This method increases the chance that your message will be read. The same way as you received this message.
Sending via Feedback Forms to any domain zones of the world. (more than 1000 domain zones.). The cost of sending 1 million messages for any domain zone of the world is $ 49 instead of $ 99. Domain zone .com - (12 million messages sent) - $399 instead of $699 All domain zones in Europe- (8 million messages sent) - $ 299 instead of $599 All sites in the world (25 million messages sent) - $499 instead of $999 Domain zone .de - (2 million messages sent) - $99 instead of $199 Domain zone .uk - (1.5 million messages sent) - $69 instead of $139 Domain zone .nl - (700 000 sent messages) - $39 instead of $79
In the process of sending messages, we do not violate the rules of GDRP. Discounts are valid until March 25.
Contact us. Telegram - @FeedbackFormEU Skype FeedbackForm2019 Email - FeedbackForm2019@gmail.com
It's time to finish.
-- This e-mail was sent from a contact form on Globe Roving (https://globeroving.com)

item.title: Globe Roving "Real VoIP savings Free SIP Trunks"
item.content:encoded:
From: RobertShary Subject: Real VoIP savings Free SIP Trunks
Message Body: We are often up to 50%-60% less than other VoIP providers.
Our VoIP pricing method is really different.
We offer free SIP/VoIP trunks and just charge for minutes. Don't worry, our service and quality is outstanding since 2009 (10 years)!
Take a look at our pricing and contact us to set up your account. Usage is month to month, with no contract jail!
https://legacyvoip.com/pricing-unlimited-sip-trunks-with-bundled-minutes-reduce-cost-now
Try us out. You really wont regret it!
Business VoIP for premises based PBXs Cloud Hosted PBXs Cloud Hosted Call Centers
We support all SIP-able PBXs and phones.
Thank you,
Bob Green Legacy VoIP
-- This e-mail was sent from a contact form on Globe Roving (https://globeroving.com)
